elements.content: To construct polyoxometalates (POMs) coordination polymers (PCPs), we prepared two pyridine ligand-functionalized Anderson POMs: (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNCH-4-Py)2]·DMF ((TBA)3POM-1, TBA = tetrabutyl ammonium, Py = pyridine, DMF = dimethylformamide) and (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2] ((TBA)3POM-2) via the postfunctionalization of (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNH2)2] (Anderson-NH2) by 4-pyridinealdehyde and 3-pyridinealdehyde, respectively. They are characterized using X-ray single-crystal diffraction, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry, electrospray ionization mass spectrometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV–visible spectroscopy, and 1H NMR. The self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-1 and [Cu­(PPh3)2­(CH3CN)2]­ClO4 (CuP2) in the mole ratios of 1:2 and 1:3 both gave the same one-dimensional double chain with the molecular formula of (NBu4) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-1)} n (7.5DMF) n (1). On the contrary, the self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-2 and CuP2 in the mole ratio of 1:2 yields a two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer of (TBA) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-2)} n ·(2DMF) n (2), while that self-assembly process in the mole ratio of 1:3 results in different 2D coordination polymer of {[Cu­(PPh3)2]3­(POM-2)·(CH3CN)} n ·(5CH3CN) n (3). Compounds 1–3 can keep their skeleton structures below 230 °C. They exhibit intense green emission (496 nm for 1; 537 nm for 2; 530 nm for 3) by ultraviolet irradiation (327 nm for 1; 303 nm for 2; 331 nm for 3), which can be tentatively ascribed as intraligand charge transfer with metal perturbation.
elements.clean_text: To construct polyoxometalates (POMs) coordination polymers (PCPs), we prepared two pyridine ligand-functionalized Anderson POMs: (TBA)3[MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNCH-4-Py)2]⋅DMF ((TBA)3POM-1, TBA = tetrabutyl ammonium, Py = pyridine, DMF = dimethylformamide) and (TBA)3[MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2] ((TBA)3POM-2) via the postfunctionalization of (TBA)3[MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNH2)2] (Anderson-NH2) by 4-pyridinealdehyde and 3-pyridinealdehyde, respectively. They are characterized using X-ray single-crystal diffraction, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry, electrospray ionization mass spectrometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV-visible spectroscopy, and 1H NMR. The self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-1 and [Cu(PPh3)2(CH3CN)2]ClO4 (CuP2) in the mole ratios of 1:2 and 1:3 both gave the same one-dimensional double chain with the molecular formula of (NBu4) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-1)} n  (7.5DMF) n  (1). On the contrary, the self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-2 and CuP2 in the mole ratio of 1:2 yields a two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer of (TBA) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-2)} n ⋅(2DMF) n  (2), while that self-assembly process in the mole ratio of 1:3 results in different 2D coordination polymer of {[Cu(PPh3)2]3(POM-2)⋅(CH3CN)} n ⋅(5CH3CN) n  (3). Compounds 1-3 can keep their skeleton structures below 230 °C. They exhibit intense green emission (496 nm for 1; 537 nm for 2; 530 nm for 3) by ultraviolet irradiation (327 nm for 1; 303 nm for 2; 331 nm for 3), which can be tentatively ascribed as intraligand charge transfer with metal perturbation.

elements.content: Assembly of organic−inorganic hybrid molecular rod consisting of a backbone of Anderson-Evans cluster and copper phosphorus building blocks in different ratio yield several luminescent polyoxometalates coordination polymers (PCPs).
elements.clean_text: Assembly of organic-inorganic hybrid molecular rod consisting of a backbone of Anderson-Evans cluster and copper phosphorus building blocks in different ratio yield several luminescent polyoxometalates coordination polymers (PCPs).

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

During the past 50 years, the research on coordination polymers (CPs) had made an amazing advance owing to enriched coordination modes of metal ions and availability of ligands with various symmetries. The directionality associated with metal ions and the tunable structures of organic ligands not only result in the multifarious structures (from one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain to three-dimensional (3D) porous framework) but also afford different functions (i.e., gas adsorption, luminescence, magnetism, or catalysis). Recently, polyoxometalates (POMs), as a novel type of inorganic ligands with high stabilities and versatile coordination modes, provide platforms for the design and preparation of highly complexed POMs coordination polymers (PCPs).
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

During the past 50 years, the research on coordination polymers (CPs) had made an amazing advance owing to enriched coordination modes of metal ions and availability of ligands with various symmetries. The directionality associated with metal ions and the tunable structures of organic ligands not only result in the multifarious structures (from one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain to three-dimensional (3D) porous framework) but also afford different functions (i.e., gas adsorption, luminescence, magnetism, or catalysis). Recently, polyoxometalates (POMs), as a novel type of inorganic ligands with high stabilities and versatile coordination modes, provide platforms for the design and preparation of highly complexed POMs coordination polymers (PCPs).

elements.content: POMs are a kind of anionic cluster with diverse structures and compositions comprising early transition metal (V, Mo, W) in their high oxidation state (+5, +6) and oxide. POMs have claimed broad applications in fields of magnetism, medicine, catalysis, and nonvolatile storage devices owing to their redox properties. Incorporation of POMs into CPs to build PCPs can not only introduce the functions of POMs into CPs but also possibly engender synergetic interaction between the POMs and CPs. Currently, three strategies have been developed to construct PCPs. The first is utilizing polyoxometalates as building blocks to build PCPs. The second is the capture of polyoxometalates cluster in the pores of MOFs. For example, Lu et al. reported a MOF consisting of sextuple intercatenation of isolated adamantane-like cages using [PW12O40]3– generated in situ as template; Zubieta et al. had prepared a porphyrin metal organic framework (PMOF) including hexamolybdates as anionic template using tetrapyridylporphyrin as linkers with the solvothermal technique. Both strategies had been very successful; however, the assembled result is difficult to predict owing to the difficulty controlling the coordination mode of POMs and the unpredictable synthetic conditions involved, which may result in structural change of POMs.
elements.clean_text: POMs are a kind of anionic cluster with diverse structures and compositions comprising early transition metal (V, Mo, W) in their high oxidation state (+5, +6) and oxide. POMs have claimed broad applications in fields of magnetism, medicine, catalysis, and nonvolatile storage devices owing to their redox properties. Incorporation of POMs into CPs to build PCPs can not only introduce the functions of POMs into CPs but also possibly engender synergetic interaction between the POMs and CPs. Currently, three strategies have been developed to construct PCPs. The first is utilizing polyoxometalates as building blocks to build PCPs. The second is the capture of polyoxometalates cluster in the pores of MOFs. For example, Lu et al. reported a MOF consisting of sextuple intercatenation of isolated adamantane-like cages using [PW12O40]3- generated in situ as template; Zubieta et al. had prepared a porphyrin metal organic framework (PMOF) including hexamolybdates as anionic template using tetrapyridylporphyrin as linkers with the solvothermal technique. Both strategies had been very successful; however, the assembled result is difficult to predict owing to the difficulty controlling the coordination mode of POMs and the unpredictable synthetic conditions involved, which may result in structural change of POMs.

elements.content: The third method is to utilize organic derivatized POMs with remote functional groups as linkers, which processes the flexible coordination ability of organic ligand while retaining the structure and function of the POMs. For instance, Hasenknopf et al. had demonstrated a supramolecular triangle utilizing (TBA)2[V6O13{(OCH2)3­CNHC­(O)-3-C5H4N}2] (TBA = tetrabutyl ammonium) and a transparent gel with birefringence using (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­{(OCH2)3CNHC­(O)-4-C5H4N}2]; Izzet et al. has reported several POMs-based supramolecular polygons (trigon and tetragon) using a pyridine group or a terpyridine-functionalized Dawson/Keggin POMs; however, only few examples of crystalline coordination polymers based on organic hybrid POMs have been reported. Hill et al. have built a coordination network using [V6O13{(OCH2)3C­(NH–CH2C6H4-4-CO2)}2]4– as linker, which can oxidize PrSH into PrSSPr using O2 as oxidizing agent. Yang et al. had reported heterometallic cluster organic frameworks using [MnMo6O18­{(OCH2)3C-4-C5H4N)}2]3– as linker and cubic [Cu4I4] cluster as node, which can catalyze three-component azide–alkyne cycloaddition reaction. The construction of CPs using organic derivatized POMs is still a challenge owing to the complicated coordination mode of POMs and stability of organic derivatized POMs.
elements.clean_text: The third method is to utilize organic derivatized POMs with remote functional groups as linkers, which processes the flexible coordination ability of organic ligand while retaining the structure and function of the POMs. For instance, Hasenknopf et al. had demonstrated a supramolecular triangle utilizing (TBA)2[V6O13{(OCH2)3CNHC(O)-3-C5H4N}2] (TBA = tetrabutyl ammonium) and a transparent gel with birefringence using (TBA)3[MnMo6O18{(OCH2)3CNHC(O)-4-C5H4N}2]; Izzet et al. has reported several POMs-based supramolecular polygons (trigon and tetragon) using a pyridine group or a terpyridine-functionalized Dawson/Keggin POMs; however, only few examples of crystalline coordination polymers based on organic hybrid POMs have been reported. Hill et al. have built a coordination network using [V6O13{(OCH2)3C(NH-CH2C6H4-4-CO2)}2]4- as linker, which can oxidize PrSH into PrSSPr using O2 as oxidizing agent. Yang et al. had reported heterometallic cluster organic frameworks using [MnMo6O18{(OCH2)3C-4-C5H4N)}2]3- as linker and cubic [Cu4I4] cluster as node, which can catalyze three-component azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction. The construction of CPs using organic derivatized POMs is still a challenge owing to the complicated coordination mode of POMs and stability of organic derivatized POMs.

elements.content: We had been devoted to the construction of organic derivatized POMs with different functional groups and in the postfunctionalization of POMs. Recently, we prepared two organic derivatized Anderson-Evans POMs with pyridyl groups: (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNCH-4-Py)2]·DMF ((TBA)3POM-1) (DMF = dimethylformamide) and (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2] ((TBA)3POM-2). Three luminescent PCPs (TBA) n ·{[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-1)} n ·(7.5DMF) n (1), (TBA) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2-(POM-2)} n ·(2DMF) n (2), and {[Cu­(PPh3)2]3­(POM-2)·(CH3CN)} n ·(5CH3CN) n (3) were obtained using them as building blocks to assemble with [Cu­(PPh3)2­(CH3CN)2]­ClO4 (CuP2). Herein, we reported their preparations, structures, characterizations, and luminescence.
elements.clean_text: We had been devoted to the construction of organic derivatized POMs with different functional groups and in the postfunctionalization of POMs. Recently, we prepared two organic derivatized Anderson-Evans POMs with pyridyl groups: (TBA)3[MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNCH-4-Py)2]⋅DMF ((TBA)3POM-1) (DMF = dimethylformamide) and (TBA)3[MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2] ((TBA)3POM-2). Three luminescent PCPs (TBA) n ⋅{[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-1)} n ⋅(7.5DMF) n  (1), (TBA) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2-(POM-2)} n ⋅(2DMF) n  (2), and {[Cu(PPh3)2]3(POM-2)⋅(CH3CN)} n ⋅(5CH3CN) n  (3) were obtained using them as building blocks to assemble with [Cu(PPh3)2(CH3CN)2]ClO4 (CuP2). Herein, we reported their preparations, structures, characterizations, and luminescence.

elements.content: Two pyridine-functionalized Anderson-Evans POMs, (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2, were conveniently obtained by the imidization reaction of Anderson-NH2 with 4-pyridinealdehyde and 3-pyridinealdehyde (Scheme S1), respectively, using the similar synthetic procedure in the literature. In the UV–vis spectra (Figure S7), the maximum absorption bands in (TBA)3POM-1 (239 nm) and (TBA)3POM-2 (236 nm) have a hypochromatic shift (26 nm for (TBA)3POM-1 and 23 nm for (TBA)3POM-2) compared to that of Anderon-NH2 (216 nm), indicating the formation of CN double bond in (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2. The 1H NMR of (TBA)3POM-1 (Figure S5) shows the pyridine ring (7.64 and 8.76 ppm), TBA signals (0.93 ppm, 1.32 ppm, 1.57 ppm, 3.17 ppm), and DMF (2.73 ppm, 2.89 ppm, 7.95 ppm). Similarly, the 1H NMR of (TBA)3POM-2 (Figure S6) shows signals of pyridine ring (7.57, 8.05, 8.43, and 8.83 ppm), the signals of TBA (0.93, 1.31, 1.56, and 3.16 ppm), and DMF (2.73, 2.89, and 7.95 ppm). Their chemical shifts and integrals are well-matched with their presupposed structures. Their electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra (Figures S1 and S2) give the characteristic peak of (M + 2H)2+ (1030.41 for (TBA)3POM-1; 1030.04 for (TBA)3POM-1; calcd. 1030.26), the characteristic peak of (M + H+ – 2TBA)− (1576.85 for (TBA)3POM-1; 1576.57 for (TBA)3POM-2; calcd. 1576.37), the characteristic peak of (M – TBA)− (1818.88 for (TBA)3POM-1; 1819.07 for (TBA)3POM-2; calcd. 1818.03). In their matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF MS) (Figures S3 and S4), the molecular peak of [M + TBA]+ (calcd. 2311.581) is found at 2311.584 in (TBA)3POM-1 and at 2311.584 in (TBA)3POM-2, which further confirmed their presupposed structures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Disscusions

Syntheses and Structures of (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2

Two pyridine-functionalized Anderson-Evans POMs, (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2, were conveniently obtained by the imidization reaction of Anderson-NH2 with 4-pyridinealdehyde and 3-pyridinealdehyde (Scheme S1), respectively, using the similar synthetic procedure in the literature. In the UV-vis spectra (Figure S7), the maximum absorption bands in (TBA)3POM-1 (239 nm) and (TBA)3POM-2 (236 nm) have a hypochromatic shift (26 nm for (TBA)3POM-1 and 23 nm for (TBA)3POM-2) compared to that of Anderon-NH2 (216 nm), indicating the formation of CN double bond in (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2. The 1H NMR of (TBA)3POM-1 (Figure S5) shows the pyridine ring (7.64 and 8.76 ppm), TBA signals (0.93 ppm, 1.32 ppm, 1.57 ppm, 3.17 ppm), and DMF (2.73 ppm, 2.89 ppm, 7.95 ppm). Similarly, the 1H NMR of (TBA)3POM-2 (Figure S6) shows signals of pyridine ring (7.57, 8.05, 8.43, and 8.83 ppm), the signals of TBA (0.93, 1.31, 1.56, and 3.16 ppm), and DMF (2.73, 2.89, and 7.95 ppm). Their chemical shifts and integrals are well-matched with their presupposed structures. Their electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra (Figures S1 and S2) give the characteristic peak of (M + 2H)2+ (1030.41 for (TBA)3POM-1; 1030.04 for (TBA)3POM-1; calcd. 1030.26), the characteristic peak of (M + H+ - 2TBA)- (1576.85 for (TBA)3POM-1; 1576.57 for (TBA)3POM-2; calcd. 1576.37), the characteristic peak of (M - TBA)- (1818.88 for (TBA)3POM-1; 1819.07 for (TBA)3POM-2; calcd. 1818.03). In their matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF MS) (Figures S3 and S4), the molecular peak of [M + TBA]+ (calcd. 2311.581) is found at 2311.584 in (TBA)3POM-1 and at 2311.584 in (TBA)3POM-2, which further confirmed their presupposed structures.

elements.content: The structure analysis by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) indicates that the asymmetric unit of (TBA)3POM-1 possesses two halves an Anderson-Evans anionic cluster of type B, three TBA cations and a DMF solvent molecule. ORTEP drawing and polyhedron diagram of POM-1 is shown in .
elements.clean_text: The structure analysis by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) indicates that the asymmetric unit of (TBA)3POM-1 possesses two halves an Anderson-Evans anionic cluster of type B, three TBA cations and a DMF solvent molecule. ORTEP drawing and polyhedron diagram of POM-1 is shown in .

elements.content: ORTEP (30% ellipsoid) diagram (a) and polyhedron diagram (b) of POM-1; hydrogen atoms and TBA cations are omitted for concision.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP (30% ellipsoid) diagram (a) and polyhedron diagram (b) of POM-1; hydrogen atoms and TBA cations are omitted for concision.

elements.content: One Mn­(III) atom in the symcenter of POM-1 is six-coordinated with six oxygen atoms from two TRIS-4-pyridine ligands to form a slightly distorted octahedron. There are six molybdenum atoms around the central Mn­(III) atom to form a planar hexagonal metal skeleton. Each molybdenum atom is coordinated with two μ3 oxygen atoms (Oc), two bridged oxygen atoms (Ob), and two terminal oxygen atoms (Ot) to form a slightly distorted octahedron. The bond lengths of Mo–Ot, Mo–Ob, and Mo–Oc are in the ranges of 1.695(3)–1.704(3), 1.909(3)–1.938(3), and 2.310(3)–2.429(3) Å, respectively. The nitrogen atom on TRIS-ligand is connected with 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde via the CN double bond (1.252(6) Å/1.217(8) Å). POM-1 is a rigid molecular rod consisting of a backbone of type-B Anderson-Evans cluster capped by two bilateral TRIS-4-pyridine ligands, which also can be viewed as the analogue of 4,4′-bipydine with the rod length of 1.89 nm.
elements.clean_text: One Mn(III) atom in the symcenter of POM-1 is six-coordinated with six oxygen atoms from two TRIS-4-pyridine ligands to form a slightly distorted octahedron. There are six molybdenum atoms around the central Mn(III) atom to form a planar hexagonal metal skeleton. Each molybdenum atom is coordinated with two μ3 oxygen atoms (Oc), two bridged oxygen atoms (Ob), and two terminal oxygen atoms (Ot) to form a slightly distorted octahedron. The bond lengths of Mo-Ot, Mo-Ob, and Mo-Oc are in the ranges of 1.695(3)-1.704(3), 1.909(3)-1.938(3), and 2.310(3)-2.429(3) Å, respectively. The nitrogen atom on TRIS-ligand is connected with 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde via the CN double bond (1.252(6) Å/1.217(8) Å). POM-1 is a rigid molecular rod consisting of a backbone of type-B Anderson-Evans cluster capped by two bilateral TRIS-4-pyridine ligands, which also can be viewed as the analogue of 4,4'-bipydine with the rod length of 1.89 nm.

elements.content: The crystal of (TBA)3POM-2 is easily to lose solvent, and X-ray data are difficult to collect. Preliminary structural analysis by X-ray single-crystal diffraction indicates that there are two half an Anderson-Evans anionic cluster and three TBA in the asymmetric unit of (TBA)3POM-2. It cannot be refined owing to the poor data quality. ORTEP drawing and polyhedron diagram of one POM-2 are shown in Figure S23. The cluster structure of POM-2 resembles that of POM-1 with different ligand of 3-pyridine. The molecular rod length of POM-2 is ∼1.89 nm, and the separation between the two nitrogen atom in pyridine ligands is ∼1.80 nm, which can be viewed as the analogue of 3,3′-bipyridine containing a POMs backbone of Anderson-Evans cluster.
elements.clean_text: The crystal of (TBA)3POM-2 is easily to lose solvent, and X-ray data are difficult to collect. Preliminary structural analysis by X-ray single-crystal diffraction indicates that there are two half an Anderson-Evans anionic cluster and three TBA in the asymmetric unit of (TBA)3POM-2. It cannot be refined owing to the poor data quality. ORTEP drawing and polyhedron diagram of one POM-2 are shown in Figure S23. The cluster structure of POM-2 resembles that of POM-1 with different ligand of 3-pyridine. The molecular rod length of POM-2 is ~1.89 nm, and the separation between the two nitrogen atom in pyridine ligands is ~1.80 nm, which can be viewed as the analogue of 3,3'-bipyridine containing a POMs backbone of Anderson-Evans cluster.

elements.content: With the technique of layer–layer diffusion, self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-1 and CuP2 in the mole ratios of 1:2 and 1:3 give lots of orange block crystals. Structure study by X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that both products crystallize in the crystal system of triclinic P1̅ space group with same cell parameters. This indicates that, despite the different mole ratios, they are the same compound of (TBA) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-1)·4DMF} n (1).
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses and Crystal Structures of Compounds 1-3

With the technique of layer-layer diffusion, self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-1 and CuP2 in the mole ratios of 1:2 and 1:3 give lots of orange block crystals. Structure study by X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that both products crystallize in the crystal system of triclinic P1̅ space group with same cell parameters. This indicates that, despite the different mole ratios, they are the same compound of (TBA) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-1)⋅4DMF} n  (1).

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit of 1, there are two halves POM-1 anions, two Cu­(PPh3)2 units, one disordered TBA cation, and four DMF solvent molecules. ORTEP drawing of POM-1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids is shown in . O1 in one POM-1 is coordinated with Cu(1), which is bonded with two P atoms from PPh3 and one nitrogen atom (N4) from one pyridine of adjacent POM-1 cluster (symmetry code: −x + 1, −y + 2, −z + 1). The pyridine N atom (N2) of POM-1 is bonded to Cu(2), which is four-coordinated to form another ONP2 tetrahedron. POM-1 can be viewed as four-connected polyoxometalates ligands coordinated with four building blocks of CuP2 to form a 1D wavelike double chain. The bond lengths of Cu–N are 2.063(4) and 2.071(4) Å, respectively. The bond lengths of Cu–P are 2.2249(13) and 2.2640(13) Å. The Cu–O bond lengths are 2.080(3) and 2.087(3) Å. The bond angles of P–Cu–P (133.27(5)°, 133.27(5)°) and N–Cu–O (96.13(15)°, 96.13(14)°) in the tetrahedron of CuP2NO are deviated from 109°28′, indicating the distorted nature in the CuP2NO tetrahedron.
elements.clean_text: In the asymmetric unit of 1, there are two halves POM-1 anions, two Cu(PPh3)2 units, one disordered TBA cation, and four DMF solvent molecules. ORTEP drawing of POM-1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids is shown in . O1 in one POM-1 is coordinated with Cu(1), which is bonded with two P atoms from PPh3 and one nitrogen atom (N4) from one pyridine of adjacent POM-1 cluster (symmetry code: -x + 1, -y + 2, -z + 1). The pyridine N atom (N2) of POM-1 is bonded to Cu(2), which is four-coordinated to form another ONP2 tetrahedron. POM-1 can be viewed as four-connected polyoxometalates ligands coordinated with four building blocks of CuP2 to form a 1D wavelike double chain. The bond lengths of Cu-N are 2.063(4) and 2.071(4) Å, respectively. The bond lengths of Cu-P are 2.2249(13) and 2.2640(13) Å. The Cu-O bond lengths are 2.080(3) and 2.087(3) Å. The bond angles of P-Cu-P (133.27(5)°, 133.27(5)°) and N-Cu-O (96.13(15)°, 96.13(14)°) in the tetrahedron of CuP2NO are deviated from 109°28', indicating the distorted nature in the CuP2NO tetrahedron.

elements.content: ORTEP diagram (30% thermal ellipsoid) of the anion in compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  ORTEP diagram (30% thermal ellipsoid) of the anion in compound 1.

elements.content: Those CuP2 units are linked by POM-1 to form an infinite spiral wavelike double chain consisting of the building block of Cu2(POM-1)2 (a,b). Those adjacent chains are further packed into a two-dimensional (2D) network with the grid of 8.3 nm × 15.2 nm via Van der Waal interaction (c,d). Those disordered TBA cations and crystallized DMF solvents are filled within these grids. Calculation using PLATON gives a potential solvent-accessible volume of ca. 24.3%, 1973.6 Å3. Other disordered solvent molecules are treated using SQUEEZE.
elements.clean_text: Those CuP2 units are linked by POM-1 to form an infinite spiral wavelike double chain consisting of the building block of Cu2(POM-1)2 (a,b). Those adjacent chains are further packed into a two-dimensional (2D) network with the grid of 8.3 nm × 15.2 nm via Van der Waal interaction (c,d). Those disordered TBA cations and crystallized DMF solvents are filled within these grids. Calculation using PLATON gives a potential solvent-accessible volume of ca. 24.3%, 1973.6 Å3. Other disordered solvent molecules are treated using SQUEEZE.

elements.content: Polyhedron viewing (a) and space-filling diagram (b) of the 1D double anionic chain in compound 1 (phenyl ring of PPh3 omitted for clarity). Polyhedron viewing (c) and space-filling diagram (d) of 2D network in compound 1 (solvent molecules and TBA omitted for concision).
elements.clean_text: 3  Polyhedron viewing (a) and space-filling diagram (b) of the 1D double anionic chain in compound 1 (phenyl ring of PPh3 omitted for clarity). Polyhedron viewing (c) and space-filling diagram (d) of 2D network in compound 1 (solvent molecules and TBA omitted for concision).

elements.content: Self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-2 and CuP2 in the ratios of 1:2 and 1:3 using a similar procedure also yielded orange block crystals. Structural study by single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the former crystallizes in the crystal system of monoclinic C2/c space group with the molecular formula of (TBA) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-2)} n (2), while the latter crystallizes in the system of triclinic P1̅ space group with the molecular formula of {[Cu­(PPh3)2]3­(POM-1)} n (3). Therefore, different ratio results in different assembled products for (TBA)3POM-2.
elements.clean_text: Self-assembly of (TBA)3POM-2 and CuP2 in the ratios of 1:2 and 1:3 using a similar procedure also yielded orange block crystals. Structural study by single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the former crystallizes in the crystal system of monoclinic C2/c space group with the molecular formula of (TBA) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-2)} n  (2), while the latter crystallizes in the system of triclinic P1̅ space group with the molecular formula of {[Cu(PPh3)2]3(POM-1)} n  (3). Therefore, different ratio results in different assembled products for (TBA)3POM-2.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of compound 2 has halves a POM-2 anion, one Cu­(PPh3)2 unit, half disordered TBA cation, and two DMF solvent molecules. The anionic ORTEP diagram (50% thermal ellipsoids) is given in a.
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit of compound 2 has halves a POM-2 anion, one Cu(PPh3)2 unit, half disordered TBA cation, and two DMF solvent molecules. The anionic ORTEP diagram (50% thermal ellipsoids) is given in a.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP diagram (50% thermal ellipsoid) of compound 2; (b) ORTEP diagram (30% thermal ellipsoid) of compound 3; TBA and DMF molecules are omitted for concision.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) ORTEP diagram (50% thermal ellipsoid) of compound 2; (b) ORTEP diagram (30% thermal ellipsoid) of compound 3; TBA and DMF molecules are omitted for concision.

elements.content: As shown in a, one terminal atom (O1) in one POM-2 is coordinated with Cu(1), which in turn is coordinated one nitrogen atom (N4) from one pyridine ligand of adjacent POM-2 cluster (symmetry code: −x + 1/2, y – 1/2, −z + 1/2) and with two PPh3 ligands to form a tetrahedron. POM-2 in compound 2 can be viewed as a four-connected polyoxometalates ligand linked by the building blocks of CuP2 to form a 2D network. The major reason for the different assembly result for POM-1 and POM-2 with CuP2 in the same ratio of 1:2 possibly arises from the larger NPyridine-Mn-axis angle in POM-2 (7.543°) compared to that of POM-1 (4.731°). The bond length of Cu–N is 2.096(4) Å, and those of Cu–P are 2.2542(14) Å and 2.2581(14) Å, respectively. The bond length of Cu–O is 2.096(4) Å. The bond angles of P–Cu–P (125.38(5)°) and N–Cu–O (102.90(15)°) in the tetrahedron of CuP2NO are deviated from 109°28′ in the ideal tetrahedron, showing the distorted nature in the CuP2NO tetrahedron.

The bond length of Cu-N is 2.096(4) Å, and those of Cu-P are 2.2542(14) Å and 2.2581(14) Å, respectively. The bond length of Cu-O is 2.096(4) Å. The bond angles of P-Cu-P (125.38(5)°) and N-Cu-O (102.90(15)°) in the tetrahedron of CuP2NO are deviated from 109°28' in the ideal tetrahedron, showing the distorted nature in the CuP2NO tetrahedron.

elements.content: The copper phosphorus units (CuP2) are linked by four-connected POM-2 to form a 2D network with the grid of 10.38 nm × 13.38 nm (a,b). Those disordered TBA cations and DMF solvents fit between the layers of the 2D network.

elements.clean_text: 5  Polyhedron graph (omitted benzene ring) (a) and spatial filling graph (b) of 2D anionic network of compound 2.

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit of compound 3, there are two halves Anderson-Evans clusters of [MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2]3– (POM-2), three [Cu­(PPh3)2]+ building blocks, one acetonitrile molecule coordinated with Cu(3), and five acetonitrile solvent molecules. ORTEP drawing with 30% thermal ellipsoid of compound 3 is shown in b.
elements.clean_text: In the asymmetric unit of compound 3, there are two halves Anderson-Evans clusters of [MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2]3- (POM-2), three [Cu(PPh3)2]+ building blocks, one acetonitrile molecule coordinated with Cu(3), and five acetonitrile solvent molecules. ORTEP drawing with 30% thermal ellipsoid of compound 3 is shown in b.

elements.content: One half POM-2 is coordinated with three CuP2 building blocks (Cu1, Cu2, Cu3) via one N atom (N4) of its pyridine ligand and two terminal oxygen atoms (O14, O15) (b), while another half POM-2 is coordinated with two CuP2 building blocks (Cu1, Cu2#1, symmetry code, #1: x – 1, y – 1, z) via one pyridine N atom (N2) and two terminal oxygen atoms­(O1) from POM-2. All copper atoms (Cu1, Cu2, Cu3) are four-coordinated with two P atoms, one N atom, and one terminal O atom to form a distorted CuP2NO tetrahedron, which is evidenced by the bonds lengths of Cu–P (2.229(3)–2.271(3) Å), Cu–N (2.029(9)–2.105(8) Å), and Cu–O (2.075(6)–2.170(7) Å); the bond angle of P–Cu–P (120.85(10)–129.73(12)°), N–Cu–P (104.5(3)–115.7(2)°), and N–Cu–O (97.9(3)–110.5(3)°).
elements.clean_text: One half POM-2 is coordinated with three CuP2 building blocks (Cu1, Cu2, Cu3) via one N atom (N4) of its pyridine ligand and two terminal oxygen atoms (O14, O15) (b), while another half POM-2 is coordinated with two CuP2 building blocks (Cu1, Cu2#1, symmetry code, #1: x - 1, y - 1, z) via one pyridine N atom (N2) and two terminal oxygen atoms(O1) from POM-2. All copper atoms (Cu1, Cu2, Cu3) are four-coordinated with two P atoms, one N atom, and one terminal O atom to form a distorted CuP2NO tetrahedron, which is evidenced by the bonds lengths of Cu-P (2.229(3)-2.271(3) Å), Cu-N (2.029(9)-2.105(8) Å), and Cu-O (2.075(6)-2.170(7) Å); the bond angle of P-Cu-P (120.85(10)-129.73(12)°), N-Cu-P (104.5(3)-115.7(2)°), and N-Cu-O (97.9(3)-110.5(3)°).

elements.content: The copper phosphorus units (CuP2) are connected by POM-2 to form a 2D network with two kinds of grids with the size of 13.94 × 14.56 nm and 13.35 × 13.36 nm (a,b). The structural difference between compounds 2 and 3 is that there are six-coordinated POM-2 in compound 3 compared to four-coordinated POM-2.
elements.clean_text: The copper phosphorus units (CuP2) are connected by POM-2 to form a 2D network with two kinds of grids with the size of 13.94 × 14.56 nm and 13.35 × 13.36 nm (a,b). The structural difference between compounds 2 and 3 is that there are six-coordinated POM-2 in compound 3 compared to four-coordinated POM-2.

elements.content: Polyhedron graph (omitted benzene ring) (a) and spatial-filling graph (b) of 2D anionic network of compound 3.
elements.clean_text: 6  Polyhedron graph (omitted benzene ring) (a) and spatial-filling graph (b) of 2D anionic network of compound 3.

elements.content: Calculations of bond valence sum (BVS) (Table S2) indicate that BVS of Mn atoms and Mo atoms in compounds (TBA)3POM-1, 1–3, are in the ranges of 3.282–3.370 and 5.925–6.082, respectively. Therefore, the oxidation state of the Mn atoms and the Mo atoms is +3 and +6, respectively. BVS results of the Cu in compounds 1–3 ranged from 0.555 to 0.632, and the oxidation state of Cu atoms in 1–3 is ascribed as +1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of compounds 1–3 was performed to further validate the oxidation state of metal. XPS spectra (Figures S16–S18) of compounds 1–3 show the characteristic Mo­(3d) doublet (Mo3d3/2, Mo3d5/2) at ca. 231.15, 234.44 eV in compound 1, 231.63, 234.89 eV in compound 2, and 231.25, 234.47 eV in compound 3, in accordance with the literature values for Mo­(VI) (231.3, 235.8 eV). The doublets of Mn­(3d) are found ca. 638.66, 649.46 eV in compound 1, 638.14, 648.0 eV in compound 2, and 638.34, 648.36 eV in compound 3, respectively, in line with the literature value of Mn­(III) (638.7, 649.7 eV). The doublets of Cu­(3d) are found ca. 932.28, 952.45 eV in compound 1, 932.83, 952.48 eV in compound 2, and 932.67, 952.62 eV in compound 3. These are consistent with the literature value of Cu­(I) (932.8, 952.2 eV). Therefore, the oxidation state of metal ions derived from XPS are consisted with that from BVS.
elements.clean_text: Calculations of bond valence sum (BVS) (Table S2) indicate that BVS of Mn atoms and Mo atoms in compounds (TBA)3POM-1, 1-3, are in the ranges of 3.282-3.370 and 5.925-6.082, respectively. Therefore, the oxidation state of the Mn atoms and the Mo atoms is +3 and +6, respectively. BVS results of the Cu in compounds 1-3 ranged from 0.555 to 0.632, and the oxidation state of Cu atoms in 1-3 is ascribed as +1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of compounds 1-3 was performed to further validate the oxidation state of metal. XPS spectra (Figures S16-S18) of compounds 1-3 show the characteristic Mo(3d) doublet (Mo3d3/2, Mo3d5/2) at ca. 231.15, 234.44 eV in compound 1, 231.63, 234.89 eV in compound 2, and 231.25, 234.47 eV in compound 3, in accordance with the literature values for Mo(VI) (231.3, 235.8 eV). The doublets of Mn(3d) are found ca. 638.66, 649.46 eV in compound 1, 638.14, 648.0 eV in compound 2, and 638.34, 648.36 eV in compound 3, respectively, in line with the literature value of Mn(III) (638.7, 649.7 eV). The doublets of Cu(3d) are found ca. 932.28, 952.45 eV in compound 1, 932.83, 952.48 eV in compound 2, and 932.67, 952.62 eV in compound 3. These are consistent with the literature value of Cu(I) (932.8, 952.2 eV). Therefore, the oxidation state of metal ions derived from XPS are consisted with that from BVS.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) of 1–3 (Figures S13–S15) are performed to validate their phase purity. These peaks of their measured PXRD spectra are in agreement with their theoretical PXRD pattern obtained from their single-crystal data (Figures S13–15), indicating that compounds 1–3 are phase-pure. Their intensity difference is possibly originated from the preferred orientation in the powder samples.
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) of 1-3 (Figures S13-S15) are performed to validate their phase purity. These peaks of their measured PXRD spectra are in agreement with their theoretical PXRD pattern obtained from their single-crystal data (Figures S13-15), indicating that compounds 1-3 are phase-pure. Their intensity difference is possibly originated from the preferred orientation in the powder samples.

elements.content: To explore thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1–3 (Figures S19–S21) was performed with the temperature rate of 10 °C/min at the N2 atmosphere. Compound 1 has a slow weight loss between 20 and 127 °C (ca. 16.4%), corresponding to loss of 7.5 DMF solvent molecules (16.61%), meaning that there are extra 3.5 DMF molecules besides these solved four DMF molecules. A rapid weight loss (ca. 39.15%) between 211 and 381 °C is associated with the loss of one TBA cation and four PPh3 ligands (39.14%). Compound 2 has a weight loss (ca. 7.7%) between 80 and 199.6 °C. This corresponds to losing two DMF molecules (5.05%); a rapid weight loss (ca. 49.02%) appeared between 227.1 and 394.6 °C, which is associated with the loss of one TBA and four triphenylphosphine ligands (44.62%). Compound 3 is stable before 100 °C; a weight loss of 9.4% is found between 100 and 230 °C, which is associated with the loss of five crystallized acetonitrile molecules and one coordinated acetonitrile molecule (7.37%); a rapid weight loss (37.1%) corresponds to the loss of six PPh3 (calc. 42.0%) between 230 and 333 °C. TGA analysis shows that compounds 2 and 3 (2D) are more stable than compound 1 (1D) with the increase of dimensionality.
elements.clean_text: To explore thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-3 (Figures S19-S21) was performed with the temperature rate of 10 °C/min at the N2 atmosphere. Compound 1 has a slow weight loss between 20 and 127 °C (ca. 16.4%), corresponding to loss of 7.5 DMF solvent molecules (16.61%), meaning that there are extra 3.5 DMF molecules besides these solved four DMF molecules. A rapid weight loss (ca. 39.15%) between 211 and 381 °C is associated with the loss of one TBA cation and four PPh3 ligands (39.14%). Compound 2 has a weight loss (ca. 7.7%) between 80 and 199.6 °C. This corresponds to losing two DMF molecules (5.05%); a rapid weight loss (ca. 49.02%) appeared between 227.1 and 394.6 °C, which is associated with the loss of one TBA and four triphenylphosphine ligands (44.62%). Compound 3 is stable before 100 °C; a weight loss of 9.4% is found between 100 and 230 °C, which is associated with the loss of five crystallized acetonitrile molecules and one coordinated acetonitrile molecule (7.37%); a rapid weight loss (37.1%) corresponds to the loss of six PPh3 (calc. 42.0%) between 230 and 333 °C. TGA analysis shows that compounds 2 and 3 (2D) are more stable than compound 1 (1D) with the increase of dimensionality.

elements.content: Because of their insolubility in common solvent, solid-state luminescence of compounds 1–3 was performed at room temperature. For comparison, the luminescence of (TBA)3POM-1, (TBA)3POM-2, and CuP2, their parents, were investigated in acetonitrile solution at a concentration of 1.0 × 10–5 mol/L. (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2 exhibit a weak emission (λmax = 331 nm) upon the excitation of 300 nm (Figure S22). CuP2 has a green emission (λmax = 508 nm) upon the excitation of 327 nm (a). The photoluminescence of compounds 1–3 (b–d) are different from that of (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2, but similar to that of CuP2. They have a broad green emission with the maximum of 496 nm for compound 1 (λex = 327 nm), 537 nm for compound 2 (λex = 303 nm), and 530 nm for compound 3 (λex = 331 nm), respectively. They can be tentatively attributed to ILCT with metal perturbation owing to their similar emission to that of triphenylphosphine ligands. Compounds 1–3 are a class of potential green-emissive hybrid materials consisting of polyoxometalates coordinate polymers (PCPs).
elements.clean_text: Because of their insolubility in common solvent, solid-state luminescence of compounds 1-3 was performed at room temperature. For comparison, the luminescence of (TBA)3POM-1, (TBA)3POM-2, and CuP2, their parents, were investigated in acetonitrile solution at a concentration of 1.0 × 10-5 mol/L. (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2 exhibit a weak emission (λmax = 331 nm) upon the excitation of 300 nm (Figure S22). CuP2 has a green emission (λmax = 508 nm) upon the excitation of 327 nm (a). The photoluminescence of compounds 1-3 (b-d) are different from that of (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2, but similar to that of CuP2. They have a broad green emission with the maximum of 496 nm for compound 1 (λex = 327 nm), 537 nm for compound 2 (λex = 303 nm), and 530 nm for compound 3 (λex = 331 nm), respectively. They can be tentatively attributed to ILCT with metal perturbation owing to their similar emission to that of triphenylphosphine ligands. Compounds 1-3 are a class of potential green-emissive hybrid materials consisting of polyoxometalates coordinate polymers (PCPs).

elements.content: Luminescence diagram of CuP2 in the acetonitrile solution (1 × 10–5 mol/L) (a), luminescence diagram of 1 (b), 2 (c), and 3 (d) in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: 7  Luminescence diagram of CuP2 in the acetonitrile solution (1 × 10-5 mol/L) (a), luminescence diagram of 1 (b), 2 (c), and 3 (d) in the solid state.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared two organic–inorganic hybrid rigid molecular rods: (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­((OCH2)3CNCH-4-Py)2]·DMF ((TBA)3POM-1) and (TBA)3[MnMo6O18­(-(OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2] ((TBA)3POM-1) by the postfunctionalization of Anderson-NH2. X-ray single-crystal diffraction shows that they are of a type-B Anderson POMs capped by two TRIS-pyridine ligands on both sides, which can be viewed as the analogue of 4,4′-bipy and 3,3′-bipy containing a polyoxometalates backbone. With (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2 as linkers to assemble with CuP2, different mole ratios of (TBA)3POM-1/CuP (1:2 and 1:3) give the same wavelike chain of (TBA) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-1)} n (7.5DMF) n (1); however, (TBA)3POM-2 and CuP2 in the mole ratio of 1:2 yields a 2D network of (TBA) n {[Cu­(PPh3)2]2­(POM-2)} n ·(2DMF) n (2), but the ratio of 1:3 ((TBA)3POM-2/CuP2) results in another 2D coordination polymer of {[Cu­(PPh3)2]3(POM-2)·(CH3CN)} n ·(5CH3CN) n (3). TGA of compounds 1–3 indicate that their skeleton can be stable up to ∼230 °C. Luminescence studies indicate that compounds 1–3 are a kind of potential green-emissive hybrid materials. Our current research not only provides a rationally strategy to build PCPs but also yields several potential green-luminescence materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have prepared two organic-inorganic hybrid rigid molecular rods: (TBA)3[MnMo6O18((OCH2)3CNCH-4-Py)2]⋅DMF ((TBA)3POM-1) and (TBA)3[MnMo6O18(-(OCH2)3CNCH-3-Py)2] ((TBA)3POM-1) by the postfunctionalization of Anderson-NH2. X-ray single-crystal diffraction shows that they are of a type-B Anderson POMs capped by two TRIS-pyridine ligands on both sides, which can be viewed as the analogue of 4,4'-bipy and 3,3'-bipy containing a polyoxometalates backbone. With (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2 as linkers to assemble with CuP2, different mole ratios of (TBA)3POM-1/CuP (1:2 and 1:3) give the same wavelike chain of (TBA) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-1)} n  (7.5DMF) n  (1); however, (TBA)3POM-2 and CuP2 in the mole ratio of 1:2 yields a 2D network of (TBA) n {[Cu(PPh3)2]2(POM-2)} n ⋅(2DMF) n  (2), but the ratio of 1:3 ((TBA)3POM-2/CuP2) results in another 2D coordination polymer of {[Cu(PPh3)2]3(POM-2)⋅(CH3CN)} n ⋅(5CH3CN) n  (3). TGA of compounds 1-3 indicate that their skeleton can be stable up to ~230 °C. Luminescence studies indicate that compounds 1-3 are a kind of potential green-emissive hybrid materials. Our current research not only provides a rationally strategy to build PCPs but also yields several potential green-luminescence materials.

cln_elements.content:
Those CuP2 units are linked by POM-1 to form an infinite spiral wavelike double chain consisting of the building block of Cu2(POM-1)2 (a,b). Those adjacent chains are further packed into a two-dimensional (2D) network with the grid of 8.3 nm × 15.2 nm via Van der Waal interaction (c,d). Those disordered TBA cations and crystallized DMF solvents are filled within these grids. Calculation using PLATON gives a potential solvent-accessible volume of ca. 24.3%, 1973.6 Å3. Other disordered solvent molecules are treated using SQUEEZE.

To explore thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1–3 (Figures S19–S21) was performed with the temperature rate of 10 °C/min at the N2 atmosphere. Compound 1 has a slow weight loss between 20 and 127 °C (ca. 16.4%), corresponding to loss of 7.5 DMF solvent molecules (16.61%), meaning that there are extra 3.5 DMF molecules besides these solved four DMF molecules. A rapid weight loss (ca. 39.15%) between 211 and 381 °C is associated with the loss of one TBA cation and four PPh3 ligands (39.14%). Compound 2 has a weight loss (ca. 7.7%) between 80 and 199.6 °C. This corresponds to losing two DMF molecules (5.05%); a rapid weight loss (ca. 49.02%) appeared between 227.1 and 394.6 °C, which is associated with the loss of one TBA and four triphenylphosphine ligands (44.62%). Compound 3 is stable before 100 °C; a weight loss of 9.4% is found between 100 and 230 °C, which is associated with the loss of five crystallized acetonitrile molecules and one coordinated acetonitrile molecule (7.37%); a rapid weight loss (37.1%) corresponds to the loss of six PPh3 (calc. 42.0%) between 230 and 333 °C. TGA analysis shows that compounds 2 and 3 (2D) are more stable than compound 1 (1D) with the increase of dimensionality.

Because of their insolubility in common solvent, solid-state luminescence of compounds 1–3 was performed at room temperature. For comparison, the luminescence of (TBA)3POM-1, (TBA)3POM-2, and CuP2, their parents, were investigated in acetonitrile solution at a concentration of 1.0 × 10–5 mol/L. (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2 exhibit a weak emission (λmax = 331 nm) upon the excitation of 300 nm (Figure S22). CuP2 has a green emission (λmax = 508 nm) upon the excitation of 327 nm (a). The photoluminescence of compounds 1–3 (b–d) are different from that of (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2, but similar to that of CuP2. They have a broad green emission with the maximum of 496 nm for compound 1 (λex = 327 nm), 537 nm for compound 2 (λex = 303 nm), and 530 nm for compound 3 (λex = 331 nm), respectively. They can be tentatively attributed to ILCT with metal perturbation owing to their similar emission to that of triphenylphosphine ligands. Compounds 1–3 are a class of potential green-emissive hybrid materials consisting of polyoxometalates coordinate polymers (PCPs).

TGA analysis shows that compounds 2 and 3 (2D) are more stable than compound 1 (1D) with the increase of dimensionality.

Because of their insolubility in common solvent, solid-state luminescence of compounds 1-3 was performed at room temperature. For comparison, the luminescence of (TBA)3POM-1, (TBA)3POM-2, and CuP2, their parents, were investigated in acetonitrile solution at a concentration of 1.0 × 10-5 mol/L. (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2 exhibit a weak emission (λmax = 331 nm) upon the excitation of 300 nm (Figure S22). CuP2 has a green emission (λmax = 508 nm) upon the excitation of 327 nm (a). The photoluminescence of compounds 1-3 (b-d) are different from that of (TBA)3POM-1 and (TBA)3POM-2, but similar to that of CuP2. They have a broad green emission with the maximum of 496 nm for compound 1 (λex = 327 nm), 537 nm for compound 2 (λex = 303 nm), and 530 nm for compound 3 (λex = 331 nm), respectively. They can be tentatively attributed to ILCT with metal perturbation owing to their similar emission to that of triphenylphosphine ligands. Compounds 1-3 are a class of potential green-emissive hybrid materials consisting of polyoxometalates coordinate polymers (PCPs).

loss of one TBA and four triphenylphosphine ligands
loss of five crystallized acetonitrile molecules and one coordinated acetonitrile molecule
